name: Hilbert–Smith conjecture
rephrased: A locally compact topological group that acts faithfully on a (topological) manifold must be a Lie group.
implication_form: If a locally compact group acts faithfully on a manifold, then it is a Lie group.
posed_by: David Hilbert and John Edward Smith
solved_by: Robert Sternberg (with contributions from others like Andrew Casson, John Frank Adams, and others, though proof verification details are complex)
explained: The Hilbert–Smith conjecture states that if a locally compact group G acts faithfully and continuously on a topological manifold M, then G must be a Lie group. In other words, any group that acts effectively on a manifold must possess a smooth manifold structure compatible with its group operations. This conjecture connects the topological properties of group actions on manifolds to their underlying smooth structure.
related_conjectures: Structure theory of locally compact groups
Actions of locally compact groups on manifolds
